revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=December 2012}} The '''1990 [[Mr. Olympia]]''' contest was an [[International Federation of BodyBuilders|IFBB]] [[professional bodybuilding]] competition held on September 15, 1990, at the [[Arie Crown Theater]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]].
==Results==
The total prize money awarded reached $200,000 for the first time ever.

|- | 1 | $100,000{{cn|date=May 2018}}

|- | 2 | $31,500 | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Lee Labrada]]
|- | 3 | $18,500 | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Shawn Ray]]

|- | 8 | | {{flagicon|Lebanon}} [[Samir Bannout]]
|- | 9 | | {{flagicon|Austria}} [[Andreas Münzer]]

|- | 11 | | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Mike Quinn (bodybuilder)|Mike Quinn]]

==Notable events==
*[[Lee Haney]] won his seventh consecutive Mr. Olympia title * This was the first drug tested contest in Mr. Olympia history

{{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = railway cricket ground Haripur | nickname = Railway Ground | image = | caption = | country = Pakistan | location = Haripur Railway Road, [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]], [[Pakistan]] | established = 2007 | seating_capacity = 16,000 | owner = Pakistan cricket Board | operator = Haripur District Cricket Association | tenants = Haripur cricket team
[[ Club cricket ]] | end2 = Pavilion end Railway road end | Cricket academy = [[ Rashid latif cricket academy ]] | Surface = [[ Grace ]] | firstodiyear = | firstodihome = | firstodiaway = | lastodidate = | lastodiyear = | lastodihome = | lastodiaway = | firsttestdate = | firsttestyear = | firsttesthome = | firsttestaway = | lasttestdate = | lasttestyear = | lasttesthome = | lasttestaway = | date = | year = }} Haripur Club Cricket Ground is also known as Railway Station Ground. It is a 16,000 Seated Club cricket ground in Haripur. the ground is located about a 5 minutes drive from Haripur city. It is the home of Haripur cricket. It is a very popular ground for club cricket matches in Haripur. The ground hosted the college tournament every year. The Pakistani left arm fast bowler Junaid khan and opener batsman Yasir Hameed also played here. . the pitch is grace and mostly bowler friendly. Seamers benefit in the late of morning. . Reconstruction:- . As the December 2013 . It was proposed to construct a stand for people at the cost of PKR 70 millions the amount is allowed from the Chief minister of KPK & minister of sport kpk ==See also== * [[Abbottabad Falcons]] * [[Pakistan Cricket Board]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * http://www.pcboard.com.pk/Pakistan/Grounds/2009.html {{coord|display=title|34.156278|73.261557}} {{Abbottabad}} {{Cricket grounds in Pakistan}} [[Category:Cricket grounds in Pakistan]] [[Category:Stadiums in Pakistan]] [[Category:Abbottabad District]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2003]] {{Pakistan-sports-venue-stub}}

The '''Badminton Hall of Fame''' honors players who have shown exceptional skill at [[badminton]], all-time great coaches and referees, and other major contributors to the game.
There is also a USA Badminton Hall of Fame <ref>[http://www.usabadminton.org/page.asp?page=Hall%20of%20Fame USA Badminton Hall of Fame]</ref> and a Badminton Canada's Hall of Fame.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.badminton.ca/Parents_and_Fans/Hall_of_Fame.aspx?sflang=en |title=Badminton Canada's Hall of Fame |access-date=2014-06-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140628152429/http://www.badminton.ca/Parents_and_Fans/Hall_of_Fame.aspx?sflang=en |archive-date=2014-06-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Members== The inaugural members 1996 were Colonel S S C Dolby Apd, [[Sir George Alan Thomas]], [[Betty Uber]] and [[Herbert Scheele]]. From 1996 to 2009 60 persons were elected to the Badminton Hall of Fame.

{{notability|Companies|date=July 2018}} {{unreferenced|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox motorsport venue |name = Berlin Raceway |nicknames = |time = [[Eastern Time Zone|Eastern (U.S.)]] |location = 2060 Berlin Fair Drive
[[Marne, Michigan]] |coordinates = {{coord|43|2|8|N|85|50|7|W|region:US_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |image [[]] --> |image_caption = |capacity = |FIA_grade = |Owner = Berlin Fair |operator = DBD Ventures |broke_ground = |opened = 1951 |closed = |construction_cost= |architect = |former_names = |events = |layout1 = |surface = |length_km = |length_mi = 7/16 mile |turns = 4 Turns |banking = |record_time = 12.513 seconds |record_driver = Brian Gerster |record_team = |record_year = |record_class = |layout2 = |surface2 = |length2_km = |length2_mi = |turns2 = |banking2 = |record_time2 = |record_driver2 = |record_team2 = |record_year2 = |record_class2 = |layout3 = |surface3 = |length3_km = |length3_mi = |turns3 = |banking3 = |record_time3 = |record_driver3 = |record_team3 = |record_year3 = |record_class3 = |layout4 = |surface4 = |length4_km = |length4_mi = |turns4 = |banking4 = |record_time4 = |record_driver4 = |record_team4 = |record_year4 = |record_class4 = |layout5 = |surface5 = |length5_km = |length5_mi = |turns5 = |banking5 = |record_time5 = |record_driver5 = |record_team5 = |record_year5 = |record_class5 = |layout6 = |surface6 = |length6_km = |length6_mi = |turns6 = |banking6 = |record_time6 = |record_driver6 = |record_team6 = |record_year6 = |record_class6 = |layout7 = |surface7 = |length7_km = |length7_mi = |turns7 = |banking7 = |record_time7 = |record_driver7 = |record_team7 = |record_year7 = |record_class7 = |Url = WWW.berlinraceway.com }} '''Berlin Raceway''' is a 0.4375 mile long paved oval race track in [[Marne, Michigan]], near [[Grand Rapids, Michigan|Grand Rapids]]. It opened in 1950. It was originally a horse track before [[World War II]]. The track is notable for the lack of an outside wall on the back straightaway, a unique feature for a national series such as [[Auto Racing Club of America|ARCA]]. In addition, the short straights make it feel almost circular. Berlin's current track record is 12.513 seconds, set by Brian Gerster in 2018 in a winged sprint car. Berlin Raceway takes its name from the city of Marne's original name "Berlin," which was changed due to Anti-German sentiment following [[World War I]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.berlinraceway.com Speedway website] * {{Racing-Reference track|Berlin_Raceway}} {{ARCA tracks}} {{NASCAR K&N Pro Series racetracks}} {{ASA National Tour racetracks}} {{USAC Silver Crown race venues}} {{USAC Stock Car racetracks}} {{World of Outlaws Sprint Car Series race venues}} {{World of Outlaws Late Model Series race venues}} [[Category:Motorsport venues in Michigan]] [[Category:ARCA Racing Series tracks]] [[Category:Sports venues in Ottawa County, Michigan]] [[Category:1950 establishments in Michigan]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1950]]

page.title: Best Athlete with a Disability ESPY Award

revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=October 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox award | name = Best Athlete with a Disability ESPY Award | current_awards = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | description = best disabled athlete | presenter = ESPN | country = | location = Los Angeles (2004) | year = 2002 | year2 = 2004 | holder = [[Kyle Maynard]] (USA) | website = {{URL|http://www.espn.co.uk/espys/}} }} The '''Best Athlete with a Disability ESPY Award''' (sometimes called the '''Outstanding Athlete with a Disability ESPY Award''') was an annual award honoring the achievements of an athlete from the world of [[disabled sports]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tfTXAQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=American+Sports:+A+History+of+Icons,+Idols+and+Ideas&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1jbbW4-3YAhWkK8AKHWosCrIQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=ESPY&f=false|title=American Sports: A History of Icons, Idols and Ideas|last=Nelson|first=Murry R.|authorlink=Murry R. Nelson|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|year=2013|isbn=0-313-39753-8|location=[[Santa Barbara, California]]|pages=399–401|accessdate=June 24, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123190837/https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tfTXAQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=American+Sports:+A+History+of+Icons,+Idols+and+Ideas&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1jbbW4-3YAhWkK8AKHWosCrIQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=ESPY&f=false|archivedate=January 23, 2018|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}} It was first presented as part of the [[ESPY Award|ESPY Awards]] at the 2002 edition as part of the ceremony's tenth anniversary of its establishment. The Best Athlete with a Disability ESPY Award trophy, designed by sculptor [[Lawrence Nowlan]],{{cite news|url=http://www.timesargus.com/article/20130802/NEWS03/708029923/0/FEATURES10|title=Sculptor commissioned to complete Joe Frazier statue has died|last=Avard|first=Christian|date=August 2, 2013|work=[[Barre Montpelier Times Argus]]|access-date=January 21, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221231935/http://www.timesargus.com/article/20130802/NEWS03/708029923/0/FEATURES10|archive-date=February 21, 2014|dead-url=yes}} was presented to the disabled sportsperson adjudged to be the best at the annual [[ESPY Award|ESPY Awards]] ceremony in [[Los Angeles]]. For the 2004 ceremony, the winner was chosen by online voting through choices selected by the ESPN Select Nominating Committee.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espy2004/s/2004/0421/1786981.html|title=The 2004 ESPY Awards - Fans to decide all 2004 ESPY Award winners|publisher=[[ESPN]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123190648/http://www.espn.com/espy2004/s/2004/0421/1786981.html|archive-date=January 23, 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=January 23, 2018|df=mdy-all}} Before that, determination of the winners was made by an panel of experts.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espy/features/01083044.html|title=Committee is newly found|date=February 3, 1999|publisher=ESPN|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123190739/http://www.espn.com/espy/features/01083044.html|archive-date=January 23, 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=23 January 2018|df=mdy-all}} Through the [[2001 in sports|2001]] iteration of the ESPY Awards, ceremonies were conducted in February of each year to honor achievements over the previous calendar year; awards presented thereafter are conferred in July and reflect performance from the June previous.{{efn|Because of the [[ESPY Awards#Timing|rescheduling]] of the ESPY Awards ceremony, the award presented in 2002 was given in consideration of performance betwixt February 2001 and June 2002.}}{{cite press release|title=New categories unveiled for The 2002 ESPY Awards|date=2002|publisher=ESPN|url=http://www.espn.com/espy2002/s/awardcategories.html|access-date=December 20, 2017|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222052554/http://www.espn.com/espy2002/s/awardcategories.html|archive-date=December 22, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The inaugural winner of the Best Athlete with a Disability ESPY Award at the 2002 edition was mountain climber [[Erik Weihenmayer]] who suffers from a total [[visual impairment]] and he became the first blind person to reach the summit of [[Mount Everest]] in May 2001.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/joshwolfe/2015/10/08/trailblazer-erik-weihenmayer-finds-blindness-no-barrier-to-adventure/#14c174fb2311|title=Trailblazer Erik Weihenmayer Finds Blindness No Barrier To Adventure|last=Wolfe|first=Josh|date=October 8, 2015|work=[[Forbes]]|access-date=October 8, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161226234919/http://www.forbes.com/sites/joshwolfe/2015/10/08/trailblazer-erik-weihenmayer-finds-blindness-no-barrier-to-adventure/#14c174fb2311|archive-date=December 26, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} He is one of three people to have won the award during its three-year history; sprinter [[Marlon Shirley]] won the accolade at the 2003 ceremony for becoming the first amputee in history to set a time below eleven seconds in the [[100 metres|men's 100 metres]] at the Utah Summer Games, and [[Kyle Maynard]] was voted the winner of the award in the 2004 iteration because of his strong form in [[freestyle wrestling]] in high school despite being born with [[congenital amputation]] that resulted in the shortening of all his limbs. The Best Athlete with a Disability ESPY Award was discontinued and bifurcated by gender in [[2005 in sports|2005]] to establish the [[Best Male Athlete with a Disability ESPY Award]] and the [[Best Female Athlete with a Disability ESPY Award]].{{cite news|url=http://www.gwinnettdailypost.com/news/kyle-maynard-wins-second-espy/article_3451efb4-06cb-505d-a03e-a4741b0b2695.html|title=Kyle Maynard wins second ESPY|date=July 10, 2012|newspaper=[[Gwinnett Daily Post]]|access-date=April 10, 2018|archive-url=https://archive.is/20180413181010/http://www.gwinnettdailypost.com/news/kyle-maynard-wins-second-espy/article_3451efb4-06cb-505d-a03e-a4741b0b2695.html|archive-date=April 13, 2018|dead-url=no}} ==List of winners and nominees== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope=col |Year ! scope=col class=unsortable| Image ! scope=col | Athlete ! scope=col | Nationality ! scope=col | Sport ! scope=col class=unsortable | Nominees ! scope=col class=unsortable | Refs |- | [[2002 ESPY Awards|2002]] | [[File:Erik in Colorado.jpg|100px|alt=Erik Weihenmayer on Mt. Sherman in 2016]] ! scope=row | {{sort name|Erik|Weihenmayer}} | {{flag|USA}} | [[Mountaineering|Mountain climbing]] | align=left | [[Stephen Pate (rugby)|Stephen Pate]] ({{flag|USA}}) – [[Wheelchair rugby]]
[[Sarah Will]] ({{flag|USA}}) – [[Para-alpine skiing|Skiing]] | {{cite news|last1=Anderson|first1=Marty|last2=Metzler|first2=Tim|title=ESPY winner (Sports & Recreation)|url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/ESPY+winner.+(Sports+%26+Recreation).-a091560668|newspaper=Paraplegia News|date=September 1, 2002|accessdate=October 8, 2018|deadurl=no|via=[[TheFreeDictionary.com|The Free Library]]}}{{cite press release|title=Paralympians Nominated For ESPY Award|date=June 11, 2002|publisher=[[United States Quad Rugby Association]]|url=http://usqra.org/before/1996-2005/22-23/stories/espy-awards.htm|last=Meznarich|first=Paul|accessdate=October 8, 2018|deadurl=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181008073943/http://usqra.org/before/1996-2005/22-23/stories/espy-awards.htm|archive-date=October 8, 2018}} |- | [[2003 ESPY Awards|2003]] | – ! scope=row | {{sort name|Marlon|Shirley}} | {{flag|USA}} | [[Track and field]] | align=left | [[Paul Schulte (basketball)|Paul Schulte]] ({{flag|USA}}) – [[Wheelchair basketball]]
[[Esther Vergeer]] ({{flag|NED}}) – [[Wheelchair tennis]] | {{cite news|url=https://newsok.com/article/1939273/despite-a-childhood-accident-marlon-shirley-seems-like-he-wasbrborn-to-runbrworlds-fastest-amputee-is-inspirational|title=Despite a childhood accident, Marlon Shirley seems like he was... ...BORN TO RUN – World's fastest amputee is inspirational|last=Ojeda|first=Francisco|date=July 29, 2003|newspaper=[[The Oklahoman]]|accessdate=October 8, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181008073944/https://newsok.com/article/1939273/despite-a-childhood-accident-marlon-shirley-seems-like-he-wasbrborn-to-runbrworlds-fastest-amputee-is-inspirational|archive-date=October 8, 2018|deadurl=no}}{{cite web|title=The 2003 ESPY Awards – Best Disabled Athlete nominees|url=http://www.espn.com/espy2003/s/03disablednominees.html|publisher=ESPN|year=2003|accessdate=October 8, 2018|deadurl=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180604233009/http://www.espn.com/espy2003/s/03disablednominees.html|archive-date=June 4, 2018|df=mdy-all}} |- | [[2004 ESPY Awards|2004]] | [[File:Kyle Maynard on Mountain.jpg|100px|alt=Kyle Maynard in 2012]] ! scope=row | {{sort name|Kyle|Maynard}} | {{flag|USA}} | [[Freestyle wrestling]] | align=left | [[Cheri Blauwet]] ({{flag|USA}}) – [[Wheelchair racing]]
[[Travis Mohr]] ({{flag|USA}}) – [[Paralympic swimming|Swimming]]
[[Ron Williams (cycling)|Ron Williams]] ({{flag|USA}}) – [[Para-cycling|Cycling]] | {{cite news|last=Morales|first=Tatiana|title=The Heart Of A Champion|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-heart-of-a-champion/|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=December 9, 2004|accessdate=October 8, 2018|deadurl=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310064022/http://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-heart-of-a-champion/|archive-date=March 10, 2016|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|url=https://www.swimmingworldmagazine.com/news/paralympic-medalist-travis-mohr-nominated-for-espy-award-vote-for-him/|title=Paralympic Medalist, Travis Mohr, Nominated for ESPY Award: Vote for Him!|date=June 26, 2004|newspaper=[[Swimming World]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181008122921/https://www.swimmingworldmagazine.com/news/paralympic-medalist-travis-mohr-nominated-for-espy-award-vote-for-him/|archive-date=October 8, 2018|deadurl=no|accessdate=October 8, 2018}} |- |} ==See also== *[[United States Olympic Committee#Awards conferred|United States Olympic Committee Paralympian of the Year Award]] *[[Laureus World Sports Award for Sportsperson of the Year with a Disability]] ==Notes and references== === Notes === {{notes}} === References === {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.espn.com.au/espys/}} {{ESPYs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Best Athlete With A Disability Espy Award}} [[Category:ESPY Awards]] [[Category:Disabled sports awards]] [[Category:Awards established in 2002]] [[Category:Awards disestablished in 2004]] [[Category:2002 establishments in the United States]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Cameron Hall | image = Cameron Hall VMI.jpg | image_size = 220px | location = 401 North Main Street
[[Lexington, Virginia]] 24450 | coordinates = {{coord|37|47|18|N|79|26|11|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = July 11, 1979{{cite book|last1=Davis|first1=Thomas W.|title=The Corps Roots the Loudest: A History of VMI Athletics|date=March 1986|publisher=UVA Print|isbn=978-0813910697|pages=152}} | opened = December 5, 1981{{cite news |title=Virginia 76, V.M.I. 49|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/06/sports/virginia-76-vmi-49.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=December 6, 1981|accessdate=March 22, 2017}} | expanded = 1995 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Virginia Military Institute]] | operator = [[Virginia Military Institute]] | surface = Costen Court (wood) | architect = Clark, Nexsen, Owen, Barbieri & Gibson, P.C.{{cite web |title=Cameron Hall - VMI Keydets|first=Aaron S.|last=Terry|url=http://www.scout.com/stadium-journey/stadium/683-cameron-hall-vmi-keydets/photos|work=Stadium Journey|date=February 25, 2017|accessdate=March 22, 2017}} | construction_cost= [[United States dollar|$]]6.8 million | seating_capacity = 5,029 | tenants = [[VMI Keydets basketball]] }} '''Cameron Hall''' is a 5,029–seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Lexington, Virginia]]. It was built in 1981 and is home to the [[Virginia Military Institute]] [[VMI Keydets basketball|Keydets]] basketball team.June 11, 2008. [https://admin.xosn.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=9800&ATCLID=1357390 Cameron Hall - The Home of VMI Basketball] Retrieved July 12, 2014. Although mainly used for basketball, the arena also holds VMI's commencement every May, as well as other large-scale events. It was named after brothers Bruce and Daniel Cameron, VMI Class of 1938 and 1942, respectively.[http://www.vmi.edu/content.aspx?id=12221 Cameron Scholarships] ==History== Built in 1981, Cameron Hall was named after brothers Bruce B. Cameron, Jr. and Daniel D. Cameron from [[Wilmington, North Carolina]].October 30, 1981. [http://digitalcollections.vmi.edu/cdm/ref/collection/p15821coll1/id/2944 "Institute Report: October 30, 1981."] Retrieved July 12, 2014. The Cameron brothers were both graduates of the school, as Bruce graduated in 1938 and Daniel in 1942. They paid for $2.3 million of the building's $6.8 million cost, with a supplementation from the [[Virginia General Assembly]].{{cite news|last=Moore|first=Hearne|date=November 13, 1981|title=Athletic Arena Opens|url=http://www2.vmi.edu/thecadet/pdfs-hi/1981/The-Cadet_1981-11-13.pdf|deadurl=yes|newspaper=[[The Cadet (newspaper)|The Cadet]]|location=[[Lexington, VA]]|publisher=Virginia Military Institute|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714143113/http://www2.vmi.edu/thecadet/pdfs-hi/1981/The-Cadet_1981-11-13.pdf#|archivedate=2014-07-14|accessdate=July 12, 2014|df=}} The other funds were paid for by the VMI Foundation. For their contributions, the Cameron brothers were given life passes to all Cameron Hall events by VMI Board of Visitors president Vincent J. Thomas. The first game was played on December 5, 1981, between [[VMI Keydets basketball|VMI]] and the [[Virginia Cavaliers men's basketball|Virginia Cavaliers]]. Virginia won the game 76–49 before 4,460 fans, which is currently the fifth-largest crowd in the arena's history.[http://www.vmikeydets.com/pdf9/2560532.pdf?ATCLID=209295912&SPSID=43813&SPID=3897&DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=9800 2013–14 VMI Basketball Fact Book] The venue seats 5,029 spectators for basketball, and 4,300 for plays and concerts.{{cite news|last=Adams|first=Theodore|date=September 25, 1981|title=Cameron Hall|url=http://www2.vmi.edu/thecadet/pdfs-hi/1981/The-Cadet_1981-09-25.pdf|newspaper=[[The Cadet (newspaper)|The Cadet]]|location=Lexington, VA|publisher=Virginia Military Institute|accessdate=July 12, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714132235/http://www2.vmi.edu/thecadet/pdfs-hi/1981/The-Cadet_1981-09-25.pdf#|archive-date=2014-07-14|dead-url=yes|df=}} It went largely untouched until 1995, when it received an extensive face lift that included repainted walls and portals, new railings, and a new floor color scheme. Locker rooms were also renovated, with new carpeting, paint, and a lounge. Four years later in 1999, a VMI "Wall of Fame" was added to the mezzanine level, which features photographs and trophies as a tribute to former VMI basketball players and members of the VMI Sports Hall of Fame. In 2007, VMI installed a new court donated by Ralph Costen, a 1970 graduate of the school. It was the first new floor since the 1995 renovation, and was appropriately named "Costen Court". ==Features== Cameron Hall serves as host to the VMI athletic department offices, and contains a library, reception area, and five racquetball courts open to cadets in the basement level. Recently, electronic side screens were added on the sidelines, as well as a "VMI Keydets" moniker that runs along either baseline under the basket. There are concessions on both ends of the arena. In July 2013, Cameron Hall was ranked among the top venues in [[mid-major]] basketball by MidMajorMadness.com.July 9, 2013. [http://www.midmajormadness.com/2013/7/9/4509244/mid-major-basketballs-top-venues "Mid-Major Basketball's Top Venues."] Parks Smith. Retrieved July 13, 2014. ==Notable Games== *'''December 5, 1981''' – In the first game in Cameron Hall history, the [[Virginia Cavaliers men's basketball|Virginia Cavaliers]] defeated VMI 76–49 before a crowd of 4,460 fans. VMI would go on to have a 1–25 season, including a 1–15 mark in [[Southern Conference]] play. *'''December 15, 1997''' – In one of the very few occasions that VMI hosted an [[Atlantic Coast Conference|ACC]] school, the #2-ranked [[North Carolina Tar Heels men's basketball|North Carolina Tar Heels]] defeated the Keydets 105–61 in front of 4,950 fans. The Tar Heels would make the Final Four of that year's [[1998 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA tournament]] and finish #1 in the [[AP Poll]]. *'''December 4, 2001''' – Featuring the second contest in Lexington between Virginia and VMI, the Cavaliers defeated the Keydets 89–70. *'''January 19, 2008''' – Off to a surprising 10–6, 2–0 start to the [[2007–08 VMI Keydets basketball team|season]], VMI battled [[UNC Asheville Bulldogs men's basketball|UNC Asheville]] in front of 4,219 spectators, which was then the third-largest crowd in Cameron Hall history. Despite a late lead, VMI lost 90–87 in overtime. *'''January 17, 2009''' – With VMI on a ten-game winning streak and off to their best start in decades at 14–2, their nearby rival [[Liberty Flames men's basketball|Liberty]] (12–6) came to Lexington in a highly anticipated match-up. The game was the largest crowd in the venue's history, as well as the first and currently only sellout with 5,029 fans in attendance. Liberty won, however, 91–80, thanks to a 35-point performance from [[Seth Curry]]. *'''March 3, 2009''' – On a Tuesday night, VMI hosted their first [[Big South Conference]] tournament game as the second seed, defeating the [[Coastal Carolina Chanticleers men's basketball|Coastal Carolina Chanticleers]] 96–76 to improve to 23–7 on the year. *'''February 2, 2013''' – In the first nationally televised contest at Cameron Hall, the UNC Asheville Bulldogs defeated VMI 90–79. The game was broadcast on [[ESPNU]]. *'''March 2, 2013''' – VMI defeated the [[Longwood Lancers men's basketball|Longwood Lancers]] on Senior Day, 94–80, to give head coach [[Duggar Baucom]] his 117th win, the most all-time by a VMI head coach. *'''November 8–9, 2013''' – The Keydets hosted the annual [[All-Military Classic]], an early-season tournament featuring the military academies of [[The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina|The Citadel]], [[United States Military Academy|Army]], and [[United States Air Force Academy|Air Force]]. After defeating [[The Citadel Bulldogs basketball|The Citadel]] 82–71 in the first game, they went on to win the tournament with a 71–63 victory over [[Air Force Falcons men's basketball|Air Force]]. It was the school's first regular-season tournament championship since the late 1970s. *'''March 22, 2014''' – VMI hosted a second-round game of the [[CollegeInsider.com Postseason Tournament|CIT Tournament]], the first national postseason tournament game held in Cameron Hall. The Keydets beat the [[IPFW Mastodons men's basketball|IPFW Mastodons]] 106–95. Propelled by [[D. J. Covington]]'s 41 points, which was a tournament record, VMI advanced to the quarterfinals. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.vmikeydets.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=9800&ATCLID=1479858 Cameron Hall - The Home of VMI Basketball] {{Virginia Military Institute}} {{VMI Keydets basketball navbox}} {{Southern Conference basketball venue navbox}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1981]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Virginia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Lexington, Virginia]] [[Category:VMI Keydets basketball]] [[Category:Virginia Military Institute]] [[Category:Event venues established in 1981]] [[Category:1981 establishments in Virginia]]

{{Infobox film | name = Celtic Pride | image = Celtic pride poster.jpg | caption = '''Theatrical release poster''' | story = Judd Apatow
[[Colin Quinn]] | screenplay = [[Judd Apatow]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Damon Wayans]] * [[Daniel Stern (actor)|Daniel Stern]] * [[Dan Aykroyd]] * [[Gail O'Grady]] * [[Christopher McDonald]]}} | director = Tom DeCerchio | producer = [[Roger Birnbaum]]
[[Judd Apatow]] | cinematography = [[Oliver Wood (cinematographer)|Oliver Wood]] | music = [[Basil Poledouris]] | editing = Hubert De La Bouillerie | studio = [[Hollywood Pictures]]
[[Caravan Pictures]] | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Buena Vista Pictures]] | released = April 19, 1996 | runtime = 90 minutes | language = [[English language|English]] | gross = $9,255,027 (domestic) |}} '''''Celtic Pride''''' is a 1996 American [[comedy film]] written by [[Judd Apatow]] and [[Colin Quinn]], and directed by Tom DeCerchio. It stars [[Daniel Stern (actor)|Daniel Stern]] and [[Dan Aykroyd]] as Mike O'Hara and Jimmy Flaherty, two passionate [[Boston Celtics]] fans, and [[Damon Wayans]] as Lewis Scott, the [[Utah Jazz]]'s All-Star [[shooting guard]]. ==Plot== Best friends for life, gym teacher Mike O'Hara ([[Daniel Stern (actor)|Daniel Stern]]) and plumber Jimmy Flaherty ([[Dan Aykroyd]]) are united by their love of Boston and its sports teams, especially the Boston Celtics, who are playing their last season in the old [[Boston Garden]]. When the Celtics drop Game 6 of the NBA Finals to the Utah Jazz, setting up a deciding Game 7 in Boston, Mike and Jimmy find themselves depressed and hopeless. On top of all this, Mike has moved back in with Jimmy after his wife Carol, fed up with his unhealthy obsession with the Celtics, left him and took their son Tommy with her. Jimmy and Mike stumble upon the Jazz's selfish, one-man-show shooting guard Lewis Scott ([[Damon Wayans]]) at a Boston nightclub. Hoping at first to get him drunk enough so he'll be hungover for Game 7, Mike and Jimmy pose as Utah fans. This however leads to them running into their idol [[Larry Bird]] (as himself), who scolds them for being what he thinks are "fair weather" fans. However, the pair get more than they bargained for when the next morning they end up kidnapping Scott after he wakes up at Jimmy's apartment. The two decide to hold Scott until after the game, reasoning that if they are going to prison, they might as well help the Celtics win in the meantime. Scott's streetwise, arrogant ways contrast with Jimmy and Mike's bumbling blue-collar lifestyle. He derides them for being washed-up losers, and insinuates Mike is only after him because he is jealous of Scott's fame and ability. Mike, on the other hand, berates Scott for his behavior on and off the court, including starring in a campy [[Oscar Mayer]] hot dog commercial and skipping practices. Scott attempts to turn Jimmy against Mike, and, when this fails, escapes, only to be foiled by an antagonistic cabbie and a local cop, Kevin ([[Paul Guilfoyle]]), both fellow Celtics fans. Ultimately, Mike challenges Scott to a game of one-on-one and the pair is incapacitated well before the final game is set to begin. Before he runs off, Scott presents the pair with a dilemma, they must root for him and hope the Jazz win, otherwise he will turn them both in to the police. Mike reconciles with his wife and son, knowing he might be going to prison, and Jimmy says goodbye to his grandmother. At the game, the two convince the other Celtics fans they are only pretending to root for the Jazz, and the first half ends with the Celtics leading. Mike, who knows the Jazz are losing because Scott refuses to pass the ball, gives him a pep talk from the stands, and Utah closes the gap to one point with a little over 7 seconds remaining. With one play left and the Jazz with the ball, Mike and Jimmy choose life over the Celtics, rooting for Utah and rushing the court after they win. Approached by Kevin who earlier ignored his cries for help, Lewis denies Mike and Jimmy committed the kidnapping, saving them from prison. A few months later, Mike has promised his wife he would never interfere with an NBA Finals game again. But now it's football season. He and Jimmy sneak into the hotel room of [[Deion Sanders]] at 3:00 a.m. ==Cast== *[[Damon Wayans]] as Lewis Scott *[[Daniel Stern (actor)|Daniel Stern]] as Mike O'Hara *[[Dan Aykroyd]] as Jimmy Flaherty *[[Gail O'Grady]] as Carol O'Hara *[[Christopher McDonald]] as Coach Kimball *[[Paul Guilfoyle]] as Kevin O'Grady *[[Adam Hendershott]] as Tommy O'Hara *[[Scott Lawrence]] as Ted Hennison *[[Deion Sanders]] as himself *[[Bill Walton]] as himself *[[Darrell Hammond]] as Chris McCarthy *[[Larry Bird]] as himself *[[Marv Albert]] as himself ==Reception== The film was not a major success despite its star power, grossing less than $10 million domestically, and received very poor reviews, with a ''rotten'' rating of 9% on review aggregate [[Rotten Tomatoes]].[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/celtic_pride/ Celtic Pride - Rotten Tomatoes] Hal Hinson of [[The Washington Post]] wrote, ''"Celtic Pride" is clearly intended as a spoof on the contemporary mania for athletics. But not only is the picture woefully short on laughs, it's also coarse, overbearing and, in places, downright insulting''[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/review96/celticpridehin.htm washingtonpost.com: A Basketball Caper That's Out of Bounds] while [[TV Guide]] said ''"Celtic Pride supplies predictably lowbrow yocks for jocks, and its rather disturbing racial implications go entirely unacknowledged,"'' and awarded it 1 and half stars out of five.[http://movies.tvguide.com/celtic-pride/review/131181 Celtic Pride Review] However, in a rare, more positive review, Joe Leydon of [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] said ''"Not quite a three-pointer, but definitely more than an airball, "Celtic Pride" is an uneven but largely likable basketball-themed comedy that should lay up decent B.O. numbers and perform even better in the homevid arena."''[https://variety.com/1996/film/reviews/celtic-pride-1200445599/ Celtic Pride | Variety] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0115851|title=Celtic Pride}} *{{rotten-tomatoes|celtic_pride|Celtic Pride}} *{{Mojo title|celticpride|Celtic Pride}} {{Judd Apatow}} {{Boston Celtics}} {{Utah Jazz}} [[Category:1990s comedy films]] [[Category:1990s sports films]] [[Category:1996 films]] [[Category:Hollywood Pictures films]] [[Category:Caravan Pictures films]] [[Category:American basketball films]] [[Category:American buddy films]] [[Category:Boston Celtics]] [[Category:Utah Jazz]] [[Category:Films set in Boston]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American sports comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Screenplays by Judd Apatow]] [[Category:Films scored by Basil Poledouris]] [[Category:Films produced by Roger Birnbaum]] [[Category:Films produced by Judd Apatow]] [[Category:Films about abduction]]

revision.text:
{{For|the screw head shape|Cheese head (screw)}}
'''Cheesehead''' is a nickname in the United States for a person from [[Wisconsin]]<ref>Kapler, Joseph, Jr. "[http://content.wisconsinhistory.org/cdm/ref/collection/wmh/id/43274 On Wisconsin Icons: When You Say 'Wisconsin', What Do You Say?]" ''Wisconsin Magazine of History'', vol. 85, no. 3 (Spring 2002), pp. 18-31.</ref> or for a fan of the [[Green Bay Packers]] [[National Football League|NFL]] [[American football|football]] franchise. The term has also been used as a derogatory nickname for Dutch people.
==Origins== The use of the term "cheesehead" as a derogatory word for Wisconsinites originated with [[Illinois]] [[American football|football]] and [[baseball]] fans to refer to opposing Wisconsin sports fans. The term, however, was quickly embraced by Wisconsinites and is now a point of pride.<ref>{{Citation | title = Foamation: About Us | url = http://www.cheesehead.com/aboutus.asp | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090302092337/http://www.cheesehead.com/aboutus.asp | archivedate = 2009-03-02 | df = }}.</ref>
The use of "Cheesehead" ([[Dutch language|Dutch]]: ''[[wikt:kaaskop#Dutch|kaaskop]]'') as slanderous term towards Dutch people<ref name=wg>{{cite web|title=What is a Cheesehead?|url=http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-a-cheesehead.htm|website=Wise Geek|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref><ref name=slur>{{cite web|title=Cheesehead|url=http://www.rsdb.org/slur/cheesehead|website=The Racial Slur Database|accessdate=11 May 2018}}{{Better source|date=May 2018}}</ref> started as early as [[World War II]], when German soldiers were known to call the Dutch "cheeseheads".<ref name=wg/> The term "cheesehead" was used in a derogatory manner in the 1969 novel ''[[Papillon (book)|Papillon]]'' to describe the jury that sentenced Papillon to life in prison.<ref>{{Citation | last = Prescott | first = Peter | page = 218 | isbn = 1-4128-0496-5 | publisher = [[Transaction Publishers]] | title = Encounters with American Culture (1963-1972) | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=loEZQgxzyQIC&pg=PA218 }}. "... and the stupiditiy of a dozen "cheesehead" jurors who couldn't care less."</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Charrière | first = Henri | title = [[Papillon (book)|Papillion]] | publisher = [[Hart-Davis, MacGibbon]] Ltd | location = France | page = 3 | isbn = 0-06-093479-4}} "Look at them, there in front of you. Can you see them clearly, those dozen cheeseheads brought to Paris from some distant village?"</ref>
==The cheesehead hat== [[File:Cheeseheads_in_Stadium_(14819823518).jpg|thumb|A [[Green Bay Packers|Packers]] fan wearing a "cheesehead" hat]]
Deena Bruno first saw a cardboard "cheesehead" hat at a [[Milwaukee Brewers]] vs. [[Chicago White Sox]] game in Chicago in 1987 worn by fellow Milwaukeean Amerik Wojciechowski.<ref>Foamation, Inc. v. Wedeward Enterprises, Inc., 947 F.Supp. 1287 (E.D. Wis. 1996)</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Cigelske |first=Tim |title=When I was 30: Michael Bednar: Cheeseheads were spreading |newspaper=[[MKE (tabloid)|MKE]] |date=September 8, 2005 |url=http://www.mkeonline.com/story.asp?id=353849 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070801032944/http://www.mkeonline.com/story.asp?id=353849 |archivedate=August 1, 2007 }}.</ref> Ralph Bruno later made the first one out of foam while he was cutting up his mother's couch. It was made popular by center-fielder [[Rick Manning]], who saw the hat while playing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.espn.go.com/greg-garber/|title=Greg Garber News, Videos, Photos, and PodCasts - ESPN|website=ESPN.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wxow.com/story/17094560/cheesehead-hat-creator-honored-by-state|title=State honors cheesehead hat creator|publisher=}}</ref> Bruno started a business to sell the hats as [[novelty item|novelties]]. The "Cheesehead" trademark is owned by Foamation, Inc. of [[St. Francis, Wisconsin]], which began manufacture of the wearable, foam "Cheesehead" in 1987. It has also been referred to as a "Cheese Hat" since it is legally a hat.<ref>{{Citation | last = Prunty | first = Brendan | title = The Origin of the 'Cheesehead' | newspaper = [[The Star-Ledger]] | date = January 19, 2008 | url = http://www.nj.com/giants/index.ssf/2008/01/the_origin_of_the_cheesehead.html}}.</ref>
In 2013, sports fans of Chicago replied to their rivals by wearing [[cheese grater]]s.<ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-12-26/news/ct-graterheads-met-20131227_1_chicago-bears-green-bay-packers-anti-packers Cheddar shredder] - Chicago Tribune, 26 December 2013</ref> {{clear}} {{Portal|Cheesehead}}
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061021205506/http://www.cheesehead.com/index.asp Foamation Inc.]

{{about|the NASCAR track in Joliet, Illinois|the former CART track located in Cicero, Illinois|Chicago Motor Speedway}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox motorsport venue |name = Chicagoland Speedway |nicknames = |time = [[Central Time Zone|UTC−6]] / −5 ([[Central Daylight Time|DST]]) |location = 500 Speedway Blvd., [[Joliet, Illinois|Joliet]], [[Illinois]] 60433 |coordinates = |image = Chicagoland-Primary-CMYK low res.jpg |image_caption = |capacity = 55,000{{cite web|url=http://www.jayski.com/news/tracks/story/_/page/chicagoland-speedway|title=Chicagoland Speedway Track News, Records & Links|website=jayski.com|publisher=jayski.com|access-date=March 5, 2016}} |owner = [[International Speedway Corporation]] |operator = |broke_ground = September 28, 1999 |opened = July 2001 |closed = |construction_cost= $130 million |architect = [[HNTB]] |former_names = |events = '''[[Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series]]'''
[[Overton's 400]]
'''[[NASCAR Xfinity Series]]'''
[[Overton's 300]]
'''[[NASCAR Camping World Truck Series]]'''
[[Overton's 225]] |layout1 = |surface = Asphalt |length_km = 2.4 |length_mi = 1.5 |turns = 4 |banking = Turns: 18°
Frontstretch: 11°
Backstretch: 5° |record_time = |record_driver = |record_team = |record_year = |record_class = |embedded = }} '''Chicagoland Speedway''' is a {{convert|1.5|mi|km}} [[tri-oval]] [[Oval track racing|speedway]] in [[Joliet, Illinois]], southwest of [[Chicago]]. The speedway opened in 2001 and used to host [[NASCAR]] racing including the opening event in the NASCAR Cup Series [[NASCAR playoffs|playoffs]]. Until 2011, the speedway also hosted the [[IndyCar Series]], recording numerous close finishes including the closest finish in IndyCar history. The speedway is owned and operated by [[International Speedway Corporation]]. ==History== {{See also|List of NASCAR race tracks}} First discussions of building a major speedway near [[Chicago]] took place in an informal meeting between [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] President [[Tony George]] and [[International Speedway Corporation]] Chief Executive Officer [[Bill France, Jr.]] in late 1995. Together they formed The Motorsports Alliance, a joint company owned by Indianapolis Motor Speedway Corporation and International Speedway Corporation. By 1995, a major racing facility had been built or was near completion near [[Las Vegas Motor Speedway|Las Vegas]], [[Auto Club Speedway|Los Angeles]] and [[Texas Motor Speedway|the Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex]]. The Chicago area was an untapped market for motorsports that had potential to be very lucrative.{{cite web|title=Chicagoland Speedway|url=http://www.chicagolandspeedway.com/About-Us/Facility-History.aspx|publisher=Chicagoland Speedway|accessdate=November 27, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101119012501/http://www.chicagolandspeedway.com/About-Us/Facility-History.aspx|archivedate=November 19, 2010|df=mdy-all}} In 1996, the search began for a site to build a speedway somewhere near Chicago. Several sites were considered, and a track was built in suburban Cicero ([[Chicago Motor Speedway]]), but eventually attention turned to the [[Joliet, Illinois|Joliet]] area where George Barr had negotiated to build [[Route 66 Raceway]]. Barr convinced Joliet officials to meet with the Motorsports Alliance to discuss building their speedway adjacent to Route 66 Raceway.{{cite web|title=Chicagoland|url=http://www.nascar.com/races/tracks/chicago/index.html|publisher=Nascar.com|accessdate=November 27, 2010}} The success of Route 66 Raceway, completed in 1998, led to the city conducting an impact study of the proposed speedway. The study revealed the new speedway would generate $300 million for the Joliet and Will County region and over 3,000 jobs. The Joliet city council unanimously approved the speedway on January 19, 1999.{{cite web|title=Joliet City Council Approves the Motorsports Alliance,LLC and Route 66 Raceway's Plans|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/government/government-bodies-offices-regional/6664696-1.html|publisher=All Business|accessdate=November 28, 2010|date=January 19, 1999}} Following the approval, the Will County Board extended the [[Des Plaines River]] Valley Enterprise Zone in order to give a tax break to the speedway developers. The tax break news also led to the Joliet High School district threatening to bail out of the enterprise zone, but a compromise was reached.{{cite web|title=Chicagoland Speedway Timeline |url=http://www.joliet.com/raceways/chicagoland/timeline.html|publisher=Joliet.com|accessdate=November 28, 2010}} In May 1999, The Motorsports Alliance combined with Route 66 Raceway LLC to form Raceway Associates, LCC with Coyne as president alongside George and France.{{cite web|title=Article: Motorsports Alliance and Route 66 Raceway Announce Transaction and Land Purchase|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-54559965.html|publisher=Highbeam|accessdate=November 28, 2010|date=May 5, 1999}} Raceway Associates revealed the track would be a {{convert|1.5|mi}} d-shaped tri-oval superspeedway. [[Joie Chitwood III]] was named vice president and general manager of the facility. During the announcement, France stated the significance of the new speedway: {{quote|The construction of a major league racing facility of this magnitude and quality in the Chicago metropolitan market symbolizes the ongoing transformation of auto racing from a narrowly-focused regional competition to a major mainstream sport. This type of racing will rival the NFL, NBA and Major League baseball for fan and sponsorship involvement. We are absolutely thrilled to be here.|[[Bill France Jr.]]}} [[File:Chicagoland Speedway ow.jpg|thumb|left|The [[IndyCar Series]] racing at Chicagoland]] Architecture and engineering firm [[HNTB]], which has built stadiums and arenas such as the [[RCA Dome]], [[Los Angeles Coliseum]] and the [[Rose Bowl (stadium)|Rose Bowl]], was selected to lead the design of the facility. Construction management company [[Bovis Lend Lease]] headed the construction of the speedway.{{cite web|title=Construction Partner Profiles|url=http://www.chicagolandspeedway.com/Articles/2000/05/CONSTRUCTION-PARTNER-PROFILES.aspx|publisher=Chicagoland Speedway|accessdate=November 28, 2010}} Construction started in August 1999, with groundbreaking September 28, 1999. On May 8, 2000, in a press conference on Chicago's [[Navy Pier]], the track's name and inaugural events were announced. Construction of the speedway resulted in a few problems. In the summer of 2000, homes near the speedway were flooded as a result of heavy rains and run-off from excavation. In February 2001, a worker was killed after falling from the skybox suites on top of the grandstands. Construction was completed in spring 2001. The track has seen little expansion since its construction, with the only major addition being the installation of lights around the track in 2008.{{cite web|title=Chicagoland Speedway announces addition of lights|url=http://www.racewayreport.com/news/chicagoland.html|publisher=Racewayreport|accessdate=November 28, 2010|date=September 25, 2007}} Phase 1 of 4; phase 4 consists of a Bristol type seating capacity completely surrounding the speedway. The Indycar Series ran at the track since 2001, recording three of the top five closest finishes in Indycar history, including the closest in 2002.{{cite web|title=IndyCar Sets Record for Entries at Chicagoland Speedway|url=http://www.chicagolandspeedway.com/Articles/2010/08/IndyCar-Sets-Record-for-Entries-at-Chicagoland.aspx|publisher=Chicagoland Speedway|accessdate=November 28, 2010}} Despite the close finishes, the speedway announced IndyCar would not return to the track for the 2011 season.{{cite web|title=Statement Regarding IZOD IndyCar Series Not Returning in 2011 |url=http://www.chicagolandspeedway.com/Articles/2010/09/Statement-Regarding-IZOD-IndyCar-Series-Not-Returning-in-2011.aspx|publisher=Chicagoland Speedway|accessdate=November 28, 2010|date=September 10, 2010}} The speedway also announced changes to the NASCAR schedule for 2011, with the NASCAR Cup Series race moving to September 16–18 as the first race in the 2011 Chase for the Championship. The [[Nationwide Series]] and [[Camping World Truck Series]] also raced the same weekend, in addition, the Nationwide Series had a stand-alone race day on June 4.{{cite web|title=Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup, NASCAR Nationwide and Truck Series|url=http://www.chicagolandspeedway.com/Tickets-Events/Events/2011/Chase-For-The-NASCAR-Sprint-Cup.aspx|publisher=Chicagoland Speedway|accessdate=November 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101126043743/http://www.chicagolandspeedway.com/Tickets-Events/Events/2011/Chase-For-The-NASCAR-Sprint-Cup.aspx|archivedate=November 26, 2010|df=mdy-all}} On May 14, 2015, Andersen Promotions, which organizes the Indy Lights series, conducted an oval test at Chicagoland Speedway, marking the first time since 2010 any level of the Mazda Road to Indy was at the track. The test was used by INDYCAR officials to give the Dallara IL-15 its first official oval laps.[http://www.indylights.com/news/belardi-auto-racing-tops-indy-lights-test-at-chicagoland] ==Track length of paved oval== The track length is disputed by the two major series that run at Chicagoland Speedway. The NASCAR timing and scoring use a length of {{convert|1.50|mi|km}}.[http://www.nascar.com/en_us/nascar-tracks/chicagoland-speedway.html Chicagoland Speedway at NASCAR.com] The IRL timing and scoring used a track length of {{convert|1.52|mi|km}}.[http://www.champcarstats.com/races/201014.htm 2010 race result on champcarstats.com] ==Races== ===Current=== * [[Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series]] – [[Overton's 400]] (2001–present) * [[NASCAR Xfinity Series]] – [[Overton's 300]] (2001–present) * [[NASCAR Camping World Truck Series]] – [[Overton's 225]] (2009–present) * [[ARCA Racing Series]] – Scott 150 (2001–present) ===Former=== * [[NASCAR Xfinity Series]] – [[Owens Corning AttiCat 300]] (2011–2015) * [[Verizon IndyCar Series]] – [[Peak Antifreeze Indy 300]] (2001–2010) * [[Indy Lights]] – [[Chicagoland 100]] (2001–2010) * [[IROC]] (2002, 2003) * [[United States Auto Club|USAC Silver Crown Series]] (2006, 2007) ==Track records== {| class="wikitable" |- !'''Record'''!!'''Date'''!!'''Driver'''!!'''Time'''!!'''Speed/Avg. {{Convert|330|ft|m|0}} }} '''Citizens Bank Park''' is a [[baseball park]] located in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] within the [[South Philadelphia Sports Complex]]. It is the home of the [[Philadelphia Phillies]], the city's [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) franchise. It opened April 3, 2004, and hosted its first regular-season baseball game on April 12 of the same year, with the Phillies losing to the [[Cincinnati Reds]], 4–1. The ballpark was built to replace the now-demolished [[Veterans Stadium]] (a [[American football|football]]/baseball multipurpose facility), and features a natural grass and dirt playing field as well as a number of Philadelphia-style food stands, including several which serve [[cheesesteak]]s, [[hoagies]] and other regional specialties. The ballpark lies on the northeast corner of the Sports Complex, which includes [[Lincoln Financial Field]], [[Wells Fargo Center (Philadelphia)|Wells Fargo Center]], and [[Xfinity Live!]]. The stadium's capacity is 43,305 seats. ==History== ===Planning=== In 1999, the Phillies and the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] of the [[National Football League]] joined their [[Western Pennsylvania]] counterparts, the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] and the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], in making requests to replace both [[Veterans Stadium]] and [[Three Rivers Stadium]] in [[Pittsburgh]] with separate stadiums. Pressure for new Philadelphia stadiums increased after a railing collapsed at The Vet during the 1998 [[Army–Navy Game]], injuring eight cadets. The Pirates threatened to leave Pittsburgh in 1997, which helped convince the legislature to approve funding for the four proposed stadiums. While Allegheny County and the City of Pittsburgh approved the pacts swiftly, due to plans already being in place at the time of legislative approval, debate within Philadelphia's city leadership carried on as Pittsburgh opened their stadiums ([[PNC Park]] for the Pirates and [[Heinz Field]] for the Steelers) in 2001. The Eagles agreed to a site slightly southeast of Veterans Stadium, which would become [[Lincoln Financial Field]]. The Eagles' stadium was built on the site of an old food warehouse and celebrated its grand opening in August 2003. [[File:"Full House at Citizens Bank Park" (Photo).jpg|thumb|left|The Phillies taking on the New York Mets at Citizens Bank Park]] The Phillies originally wanted a downtown ballpark similar to [[Oriole Park at Camden Yards|Baltimore]], [[Coors Field|Denver]], [[Great American Ball Park|Cincinnati]], [[Progressive Field|Cleveland]], [[Comerica Park|Detroit]] and [[AT&T Park|San Francisco]]. Various locations were proposed, initially at Broad and Spring Garden streets, Spring Garden and Delaware Avenue and next to [[30th Street Station]], where the main post office was located. The team and the city announced that the site would be at 13th and Vine streets in [[Chinatown, Philadelphia|Chinatown]], just north of Interstate 676, within walking distance of [[Center City Philadelphia|Center City]]. There was considerable support for a downtown ball park from business and labor and the city at large. However, Chinatown residents protested, fearing a new ballpark would destroy their neighborhood. The City and team eventually settled on building at the South Philadelphia Sports Complex, on the site of an old food warehouse much like Lincoln Financial Field. In the years that followed, residents, fans and owner [[Bill Giles (baseball)|Bill Giles]] expressed regret that the new ball park was not located in Center City. Regardless of location, the team set records in [[2010 Philadelphia Phillies season|2010]] for attendance (3,647,249 fans, averaging 45,028) and sellouts (81), extending a streak dating back to July of [[2009 Philadelphia Phillies season|2009]] to 123 straight sellouts.[http://sportsnetwork.com/merge/tsnform.aspx?c=sportsnetwork&page=mlb/teams/008/attendance.aspx?team=008 Phillies attendance figures] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716125657/http://sportsnetwork.com/merge/tsnform.aspx?c=sportsnetwork&page=mlb%2Fteams%2F008%2Fattendance.aspx%3Fteam%3D008 |date=2011-07-16 }}, sportsnetwork.com, retrieved October 6, 2010. The new stadium was designed by [[EwingCole]]'s [[Stanley Cole (architect)|Stanley Cole]], who was the stadium's chief architect.{{cite news|first=Bonnie L.|last=Cook|title=Stanley M. Cole, 89, architect of ballpark |url=http://articles.philly.com/2013-03-16/news/37747592_1_ewingcole-architect-phillies-charities |work=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]] |publisher=[[Philly.com]] |date=2013-03-16 |accessdate=2013-04-05}} The unveiling of the park and ground breaking ceremonies were on June 28, 2001. Following the game that evening, the location of the left-field foul pole was unveiled at the outset of the team's annual 4 July fireworks display. On June 17, 2003, [[Citizens Financial Group|Citizens Bank]] agreed with the team to a 25-year, [[United States dollar|US $]]95 million deal for [[naming rights]] and advertising on telecasts, radio broadcasts, publications and inside the facility.{{cite news |last=[[Associated Press]]|title=Proud Citizens: Phillies new stadium to be called Citizens Bank Park|date=June 17, 2003|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/baseball/news/2003/06/17/phillies_citizens_ap/|accessdate=April 7, 2009}} The ballpark was officially topped off on August 12, 2003, and opened in April 2004. ===Modifications=== Shortly after the park opened in 2004, the [[bullpen]]s were reassigned so the Phillies' pitchers used the lower pen and visitors use the upper pen. This was done to give Phillies' pitchers a better view of the game and to protect them from heckling by rowdy fans.{{cite news|title=Urban View at Phillies' New Park Is So-So, but Hitters Are Regularly Dialing Downtown|first=Bill|last=Center|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20040517/news_lz1s17phils.html|newspaper=[[U-T San Diego|The San Diego Union-Tribune]]|date=May 17, 2004|accessdate=June 25, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050321034759/http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20040517/news_lz1s17phils.html|archivedate=March 21, 2005|df=}} However, the team forgot to rewire the bullpen phones after the bullpens were reassigned; so during the first game, the dugout coaches had to communicate with the bullpens by hand signals. In its first years, Citizens Bank Park allowed 218 home runs in 2004 and 201 in 2005. More than half of those home runs were to left-field. Following the 2005 season, the left-field wall was moved back {{Convert|5|ft|m}}.[http://philadelphia.phillies.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20051028&content_id=1262133&vkey=news_phi&fext=.jsp&c_id=phi Phillies.com] "Citizens Bank Walls to Be Moved Back" Retrieved June 25, 2009 Even with these modifications, the park has a reputation as one of the most hitter-friendly parks in baseball.[http://.go.com/mlb/stats/parkfactor Citizens Bank Park listed by as 12th most hitter-friendly park in [[MLB]] for 2009]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 2009, it gave up 149 home runs, the most in the National League and second in the majors behind only [[Yankee Stadium|the new Yankee Stadium]], but has been neutral since, with a .997 [[park factor]] in 2011.{{cite web |title=2011 MLB Park Factors|url=http://espn.go.com/mlb/stats/parkfactor/_/year/2011|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=August 25, 2013}} ==Significant events== [[Image:Thome400HR.JPG|thumb|left|The plaque marking the landing point of Jim Thome's 400th career home run]] *[[Randy Wolf]] of the Phillies threw the first pitch at 1:32 pm EDT on April 12, 2004 to [[D'Angelo Jiménez]] of the Reds, who got the park's first hit, a lead-off double. [[Bobby Abreu]] of the Phillies hit the first home run, which also served as the franchise's first hit in the club's new home. Reds pitcher [[Paul Wilson (baseball)|Paul Wilson]] earned the first win in that game and [[Danny Graves]] earned the park's first save.{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/PHI/PHI200404120.shtml|title=April 12, 2004 Cincinnati Reds at Philadelphia Phillies Box Score and Play by Play|accessdate=April 1, 2009|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|date=April 12, 2004}} *On June 14, 2004, Phillies first baseman [[Jim Thome]] hit his 400th career home run to the left-center field seats at Citizens Bank Park.{{cite news |title=BASEBALL ROUNDUP: Thome Hits 400th Home Run of Career|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/15/sports/baseball-roundup-thome-hits-400th-home-run-of-career.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 15, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2009}} *The first [[inside-the-park home run]] was hit by [[Jimmy Rollins]] on June 20, 2004, against the [[Kansas City Royals]]. *The [[Eastern League (baseball)|Eastern League]] [[Reading Phillies]] hosted the [[Trenton Thunder]] on May 9, 2005 at CBP;{{cite web |title=A Night of Lasting Impressions for Minor Leaguers; Trenton, Reading Players Revel in Special Game at Citizens Bank Park|first=Kent|last=Malmros|url=http://www.minorleaguebaseball.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20050510&content_id=4174&vkey=news_milb&fext=.jsp|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=May 10, 2005|accessdate=April 26, 2009}} Reading beat Trenton 5–3.{{cite news |title=Thunder Rained on by Reading|url=http://articles.philly.com/2005-05-10/sports/25440509_1_blue-rocks-red-barons-pawtucket|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=May 10, 2005|accessdate=April 26, 2009|pages=D05}} [[File:Citizens Bank Park in 2010.jpg|thumb|Citizens Bank Park in 2010]] *On September 14, 2005, [[Andruw Jones]] of the [[Atlanta Braves]] hit his 300th career home run which went {{convert|430|ft|m}} off Phils reliever [[Geoff Geary]] in a 12–4 Phillies win.{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/PHI/PHI200509140.shtml|title=September 14, 2005 Atlanta Braves at Philadelphia Phillies Box Score and Play by Play|accessdate=April 1, 2009|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|date=September 14, 2005}} The ball landed in the upper deck in left field.{{cite news |first=Mark|last=Bowman|title=Andruw Hits Two Milestones With Homer; Braves Center Fielder Belts No. 50 of 2005, No. 300 of Career|date=September 14, 2005|work=[[MLB.com]]|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20050914&content_id=1210307&vkey=recap&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|accessdate=April 1, 2009}} *The Phillies lost their 10,000th regular-season game in their history{{cite news |first=Stephen|last=Fastenau|title=Phils Handed 10,000th Loss; Right-hander Eaton Allows Six Runs in Four-Plus Innings|date=July 15, 2007|work=[[MLB.com]]|url=http://philadelphia.phillies.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20070715&content_id=2089066&vkey=recap&fext=.jsp&c_id=phi|accessdate=April 1, 2009}} on July 15, 2007 to the St. Louis Cardinals, 10–2,{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/PHI/PHI200707150.shtml|title=July 15, 2007 St. Louis Cardinals at Philadelphia Phillies Box Score and Play by Play|accessdate=April 1, 2009|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|date=July 15, 2007}} marking the first time a professional sports franchise reached that plateau.{{cite news |first=Mel|last=Antonen|title=Phillies Are No. 1 in Loss Column|date=July 16, 2007|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/nl/phillies/2007-07-02-Loser-Phillies_N.htm|accessdate=April 1, 2009}} [[Image:Phillies board.JPG|thumb|right|The scoreboard when the Phillies won the 2008 World Series]] *The park hosted its first [[World Series]] game on October 25, 2008, with the Phillies defeating the [[Tampa Bay Rays]], 5–4 in Game 3.{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/PHI/PHI200810250.shtml|title=October 25, 2008World Series Game 3 at Citizens Bank Park Play by Play and Box Score|accessdate=April 1, 2009|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|date=October 25, 2008}} Before the game, [[country music]] singer [[Tim McGraw]], the son of the late Phillies closer [[Tug McGraw]] (who had recorded the last out in the Phillies' World Series victory in {{wsy|1980}}), took a handful of his dad's ashes and spread them on the [[pitcher's mound]] just before handing the ball used in throwing out the [[ceremonial first pitch]] in the game to [[Steve Carlton]].{{cite news |first=Kevin|last=Kaduk|title=Tim McGraw Spreads His Father's Ashes on World Series Mound|date=October 26, 2008|work=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/mlb/blog/big_league_stew/post/Tim-McGraw-spreads-his-father-s-ashes-on-World-S?urn=mlb,117404|accessdate=April 1, 2009}} The elder McGraw died from a [[brain tumor]] in 2004.{{cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Colorful McGraw Had Brain Cancer|date=February 12, 2004|publisher=[[ESPN]]|url=http://espn.go.com/classic/obit/s/2004/0105/1701174.html|accessdate=April 3, 2009}} Four days later, the Phillies completed a suspended [[2008 World Series#Game 5|Game]] 5, defeating the Rays, 4–3, and claiming the franchise's second World Series championship in front of a park record crowd of 45,940.{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/PHI/PHI200810270.shtml|title=October 27, 2008 World Series Game 5 at Citizens Bank Park Play by Play and Box Score|accessdate=April 1, 2009|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|date=October 27, 2008}} The Phillies held their post-parade celebration at the park on October 31. *On June 25, 2010, Citizens Bank Park hosted the first regular-season game in a [[National League]] stadium in which the [[designated hitter]] was used; Major League Baseball moved the Phillies' series against the [[Toronto Blue Jays]] from [[Rogers Centre]] to Philadelphia, citing security concerns for the [[2010 Toronto G-20 Summit|G-20 Summit]]. [[Ryan Howard]] served as the first DH in a [[National League]] ballpark. Despite playing in their park, Philadelphia was designated as the road team. *The first [[no-hitter]] at Citizens Bank Park was thrown by [[Roy Halladay]] on October 6, 2010 against the [[2010 Cincinnati Reds season|Cincinnati Reds]] in the first game of the [[2010 National League Division Series#Philadelphia Phillies vs. Cincinnati Reds|2010 NLDS]]. ==Features== ===Ashburn Alley=== {{Main article|Ashburn Alley}} [[Image:Phillies Wall of Fame.jpg|thumb|450px|[[Philadelphia Baseball Wall of Fame]]]] Behind center field is Ashburn Alley, named after Phillies [[Baseball Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] center fielder [[Richie Ashburn]], who played for the team from 1948 to 1959 and was a Phillies broadcaster from 1963 until his death in 1997. It is seen by Phillies fans as a compromise between the Phillies and their fans, many of whom wanted Citizens Bank Park named in honor of Ashburn. Ashburn Alley is named for the slightly-overgrown grass which bordered the third base line at [[Shibe Park]] where Ashburn was famous for laying down bunts that stayed fair. The new Ashburn Alley, located near Ashburn's defensive position, is a walkway featuring restaurants, games and memorabilia from Phillies history. Ashburn Alley also features a memorabilia shop and a large bronze statue of Ashburn directly behind center field, as well as the [[flag of the United States|U.S. flag]], the flags of the Commonwealth of [[Pennsylvania]] and the City of [[Philadelphia]], a [[POW/MIA flag]] and the flags from the Phillies' championships (below). {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! style="text-align:center;
